isis.stitle: Electrical System Troubleshooting Guide - BE 200, CE 200, CE 300 Model - BATTERY, CHARGING AND CRANKING SYSTEMS - ENGINE CRANKING - CRANKING MOTOR SYSTEM CIRCUITS AND COMPONENTS

svcproc.title: CRANKING MOTOR SYSTEM CIRCUITS AND COMPONENTS

svcsubproc.title: Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1

Starter shifting in and out, or not pulling in, is often caused by high resistance in the cranking motor solenoid circuit. When the solenoid circuit has excessive voltage loss, the cranking motor pinion may not engage the flywheel. If it does engage, it may drop out too soon when battery voltage drops. The solenoid circuit includes the Starter ISO & Power relay (4003) (located in the engine power distribution center) and circuits connected to the cranking motor solenoid.
On vehicles with overcrank protection, refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System before performing this test.

step1.para: Disconnect starter relay circuit K17F from the starter solenoid "S" terminal.

Connect the carbon pile positive lead to circuit K17F and the negative lead to the cranking motor ground. Connect the positive lead of a DMM voltmeter to the solenoid "B" terminal. Connect negative lead of voltmeter to switch wire lead K17F (not to carbon pile clamp). Meter will show battery voltage.

Have an assistant turn the key switch to the start position or push start button. Voltmeter reading should be zero. You should hear the starter relay energize with a clicking sound. If the switch does not "click," either the starter relay switch is faulty or there is no voltage from the key switch circuit (refer to Starter ISO & power relay circuits.

Turn on and adjust the carbon pile to 50 amp load (for no more than 10 seconds). Read and record __________voltage on voltmeter. Release start switch. Turn off and disconnect carbon pile and voltmeter.

svcsubproc.para: If circuit loss is 0.5 volt or less, Starter solenoid circuitry is OK.
If circuit loss is more than 0.5 volt, go to Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2.

figure.caption: Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1

svcsubproc.title: Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss)
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss).

If the voltage loss in the previous Test was more than 0.5 volt, the loss is excessive. The loss may be from loose terminals, corrosion, or a worn out Starter ISO & Power relay (4003). To locate the problem:

step1.para: Disconnect circuit K17F from "S" terminal at Cranking Motor solenoid. Connect carbon pile to circuit K17F and to cranking motor ground terminal. Turn the carbon pile on (will show 0 amps).
Disconnect Starter ISO & Power relay (4003) and install a jumper lead to (4003) cavity 30, circuit K17D.

note.para: Test lead will be at battery voltage.

step1.para: Connect DMM from solenoid BAT terminal to Starter ISO & Power relay (4003) cavity 30, circuit K17D (will show zero volts).

At relay connector, install other end of jumper lead to cavity 87 circuit K17F. Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record first wire voltage loss. Disconnect DMM.
At relay connector, connect DMM from cavity 30, K17D to circuit K17F at carbon pile. Connect to terminal and not to carbon pile clamp.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record second wire voltage loss. Disconnect and remove jumper lead and DMM.

svcsubproc.para: First Wire Loss (step 3) ________
plus Second Wire Loss (step 5) ________
equals Total Wiring Loss = _________(0.4V maximum loss)
If wiring loss is 0.4 volt or less, repair or replace wire(s), and retest per Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1, above.
If wiring loss is more than 0.4 volt, repair or replace wire(s), and retest per Part 1.
If retest results are still above 0.5 volt loss, replace starter relay and retest per Part 1.

figure.caption: Cranking Motor Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Wire Voltage Loss)

svcsubproc.title: Cranking Motor Replacement Test
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Cranking Motor Replacement Test.
A. COLD WEATHER START MAGNETIC SWITCH PROBLEMS

The start relay can fail to "hold in" during cold weather cranking due to low voltage, even though the switches and circuits check good. This failure sounds as though the cranking motor is failing to stay engaged to the flywheel. It is caused by low system voltage releasing the relay.
If this condition exists, momentarily install jumper wire from circuit K17D to K17F at Starter ISO & Power relay connector (4003).

caution.para: The studs or terminals are at battery voltage and the engine should crank when the jumper is connected. Remove jumper to stop cranking.

svcsubproc.para: If the engine cranks properly with jumper in place, replace the relay.
B. CHECKING AVAILABLE VOLTAGE AT CRANKING MOTOR
If all previous tests have been performed, the vehicle batteries and cranking motor wiring have been checked. If the engine still cranks slowly, check available voltage at the cranking motor.

step1.para: While cranking engine, measure voltage between the cranking motor solenoid "BAT" stud and cranking motor ground.

step2.para: If voltage is 9.0 volts or more, the problem must be in the cranking motor (or engine). Replace the cranking motor.
If the voltage is less than 9.0 volts, go to step 2.

step1.para: Check the interconnecting cable between the batteries. While cranking, measure the terminal voltage of each battery by touching voltmeter leads to the post of each battery.

step2.para: If the difference between any two battery readings in the same battery box is more than 0.5 volt or any cable is warm to the touch, replace the interconnecting cables.
If cables check OK, the problem must be in the Cranking Motor (or engine). Replace the Cranking Motor.

svcsubproc.title: Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System
svcsubproc.para: The thermal overcrank circuit interrupts the ground signal from the engine controller to the starter ISO & power relay when the engine has been cranking too long and the starter is overheating. Problems with the circuits could be the result of a failed thermal switch or open or shorted circuits.

entry.para: Check with (6316) removed, key in start position, all relays installed and transmission in PARK.

note.para: Always check connectors for damage and pushed-out terminals.

entry.para: Thermal overcrank connector on starter motor.
Resistance across terminals should be < 2 ohms when starter is cool.
If resistance is high, replace thermal switch.
If relay passes test, go to next step.
(6316) harness connector cavity B to ground.
If voltage is missing, check for open or short in circuits K17K between (6316) and starter relay (4003).
(6316) harness connector cavity B to cavity A.
If voltage is missing, check for open in circuit K17L to engine controller.
If circuit checks good refer to engine manual to troubleshoot missing ground from engine controller.
